definitions.definition: A person who gave or supposedly gave their name to a people , place , institution , etc.
examples: The Greeks and Romans tended to credit nearly every location and ethnicity to a legendary eponym , Hellas to Hellen , Rome to Romulus , Egypt to Aegyptus , etc.
Similar to the Greek eponymous archons and Roman consuls , the names of the annually appointed Assyrian limus were used for their years in office and they are accordingly also known as eponyms .

definitions.definition: Something that is named after a person .
A name taken from a person , a namesake toponym , term , etc.
examples: Alexandria is an eponym , taken from its founder Alexander the Great .

definitions.definition: A name or term derived from any proper noun , inclusive of places , brands , etc.
examples: " Tangerine " is an eponym in reference to Tangier ... The unflattering eponym " shanghai " derived from the behavior of American shippers, not the Chinese themselves...

definitions.definition: Synonym of epitome , a person taken as a symbol or quintessential representative of some trait , school , etc.
examples: Rockefeller became the very eponym of wealth.

definitions.definition: Synonym of epithet , a distinguishing title .
examples: It was only posthumously that Julian was distinguished with the eponym "Apostate".

main_definition: A person who gave or supposedly gave their name to a people , place , institution , etc.
secondary_definitions: Something that is named after a person .
( sometimes proscribed ) A name taken from a person , a namesake toponym , term , etc.
( loosely , sometimes proscribed ) A name or term derived from any proper noun , inclusive of places , brands , etc.
( archaic ) Synonym of epitome , a person taken as a symbol or quintessential representative of some trait , school , etc.
( archaic ) Synonym of epithet , a distinguishing title .
